ygData.messageBody:
The only thing I would disagree on is the Paladins healing
skills. I have not found a subclass that can heal me before
they run out of mana (if I get into a serious fight). Being a
barbarian warrior of lower intelligence, I like banging with a
creature until he has me down to less than a bubble of
health then killing him with 18 hps left :)

> ----------
> From: David Rogers[SMTP:derogers334@...]
> Reply To: warriors_eq@onelist.com
> Sent: Monday, May 24, 1999 3:01 PM
> To: warriors_eq@onelist.com
> Subject: Re: [warriors_eq] Rangers and warriors
>
> From: David Rogers <derogers334@...>
>
> --- Jason Coan <COANJ@...> wrote:
> > The game isn't based upon solo play, and after about
> > 20th lvl you basically can't solo. So whats it
> > matter if a 12th lvl paladin has a few minutes
> > quicker recovery at LOW level. I never fought solo
> > past about 9 anyways.
>
> That's a play style decision, not a numbers one. I'm speaking only to
> the numbers. Minute for minute, Warriors can't solo as efficiently as
> other classes can. Verdant does heavily encourage grouping, so once
> you find even one other person to group with, you are enabled to begin
> ignoring certain disadvantages of one class or the other; but sometimes
> you're knocking around alone, and Warriors have a tougher time doing
> that than other classes.
>
> > Paladins don't have the HP of a warrior, so they
>
> They're not so far behind. I've heard the number 25% less mentioned a
> few times; if true, it's significant, but not massively so. 25% of 100
> is only 25, which isn't very much from a high level mob. 25% of 1000
> is 250, which is a larger number (but still the same fraction); but,
> again, 250 isn't so terribly much when considered against the damage
> output of a high level mob.
>
> > can't tank as long. They don't have their
> > dodge/parry/reposte are several levels behind a
> > warrior, meaning they never get those skills as high
> > as a warrior of the same level. Add that in with
>
> Ok, here I disagree. My Dwarven Paladin (my main character) received
> Dodge at 10; by 12 and since then (currently 15th), it's been level
> capped. That was from a skill score of *1*, up to the level cap
> (5+(12*5)=65 at 12th). Only 2 levels, not so long. The Paladin had to
> wait longer to get it, but now the Paladin is just as good with it as
> the Troll Warrior I also run (though the Troll's lower in level). I've
> had a much harder time keeping skills level capped with the Troll than
> with the Dwarf; though the Dwarf does have about 20 or so more points
> of Int (could be a bit more, I'd have to check).
>
> > their lesser HP and there is a huge difference. Ok,
> > so the paladin can help heal himself after a
> > fight.....whooptee, if he were a fighter he wouldn't
> > have so much to be healed anyways. not like a 25
> > point heal at 25th lvl is going to do much anyways.
>
> Again, if you say so. With the Paladin, the heals do make a difference
> in downtime. The reason my other character is a Troll Warrior is for
> regen; one of my main goals in EQ is to minimize downtime between
> 'action'. Whether grouped or solo, both characters have something they
> can use without looking to anyone else to reduce their downtime. If I
> knew I always had a healer available, I'd play an Ogre instead of a
> Troll; but because you can't always depend on having a heal present, I
> play with Regen when I go Warrior.
>
> Warriors would be better off if bandages weren't so *damn* expensive,
> IMO. Bandages should go for 1sp each; they're just rags that've been
> washed and sterilized in hot water, after all.
>
> > I've found kick to be almost as good as bash, you'd
> > be suprised at how often a 15 point kick will
> > disrupt a caster.
>
> Kick does more damage, but has a markedly lower percentage chance to
> disrupt the casting. Bash will far more often interrupt the spell.
> Vs. NPC wizards, for example, this is damn critical. I use kick with
> my Troll to finish off fleeing opponents when they're almost dead; but
> use Slam most all the time for the stun chance. After having been
> stunned all the time by everything *I* fight, it's nice to watch a mob
> stand there for a few seconds while you whack on it.
>
> > EXACTLY warriors tank, paladins attempt to tank.
> > The damage either deals is minimal, both are in the
> > party for one reason....to keep the casters alive
> > long enough to kill the mobs. So what would be
> > better, a tank that can absorb all the damage with
> > fewer heals required by the cleric, or a semi-tank
> > that requires more heals from the cleric, thus more
> > of a chance the monster will jump the cleric?
>
> If you're looking for a "X class is the best, period" answer in this
> debate, I seriously doubt you'll find it. Verdant has done a pretty
> good job of balancing the classes; there really isn't any one perfect,
> or 'best' class. Warriors have pros and cons, as do the warrior
> subclasses, as do the Mages, as do the mage subclasses. Each has a
> style of play that's either slightly or massively different from the
> other. It comes down to personal preference and available resources.
>
> Examples:
>
> Warriors have to pair with a Cleric (or any mage subclass with healing
> spells, or even a Paladin, who also has healing); because otherwise the
> downtime after fights will catch up with them. Even pairing with other
> Warriors, or with Wizards/Magicians won't work around this; Warriors
> will have to have a healer present to counteract their innate
> disadvantage of requiring healing at the higher levels. SKs are in
> this boat too; they get tricks, but no heals; and so need the healing
> too.
>
> Paladins can self-heal, which enables a Paladin to fairly efficiently
> team without a healer present. After my favorite pairing
> (Paladin/Wizard), my next most favorite pairing is (Paladin/Warrior);
> because we're both solid melee combatants, and the Paladin can keep
> both topped off.
>
> But again, it's just a matter of style and resources present.
>
> > 2 tanks, why do you need a paladin? More than 2
>
> See above; Paladin acts as second mini-cleric. Just as 2 warriors help
> spread the tanking between themselves (reducing the danger and overall
> HP load that would be more onerous to a single tank), a Paladin helps
> spread the healing load on the single cleric, yet doesn't force the
> party to have a second guy (second cleric) standing around waiting for
> the tanks to drop. A Paladin can swing with the warriors and then step
> back to heal, then step back in. It splits the difference between a
> 3rd tank and a cleric nicely, IMO.
>
> Also, I like having tanks/fighters along; any full group I formed up
> would preferably have 3 fighter classes present, and *at least* 1
> Warrior.
>
> > But to sum up, paladins sacrifice so much melee
> > ability for so little casting ability which
>
> I'm confused where you're getting this 'sacrifice so much melee
> ability' thing from? Paladin combat skills are level with Warriors'.
> The only main difference is at which point a particular skill shows up
> (no kick or dual wield, and everything else 3-5 levels after the
> Warrior receives it), and the lower hps.
>
> It's ok to not like a particular class; I hate rogues and druids, for
> example. But there's a difference between simply disliking a class for
> astetic or personal opinion reasons, and the class flat out being
> inferior. No class in EQ is flat out inferior. Each is simply tuned
> in a certain way. You find what best suits your own natural
> inclinations as a player, and off ya go!
>
